Notes: The source is unclear on whether the scales are Folk-scales, rather than classical tradition.
As far as JMcB can tell, this could apply to all Arab countries, but there will be some sort of regional differences. Language is a proximate connection.

These scales are a classical tradition. The music does not necessarily reflect a single ethnic group, but we offer a suggestion based on historical relationships we link this scale to Iranian - following the ethnolinguistic trdition observed in D-PLACE. In D-PLACE, the Persian language is linked to Ea9 (Iranian), Ea6 (Basseri), and SCCS58 (Basseri) within the Indo-European phylogeny.

The instrument is of Portuguese provenance, and the measurement is taken from the North-Eastern state of Piaui. The data is taken from another source, but I can't find it online so this is all I've got. I found another source (M. Mendes) with similar data.

The title of the primary source is "MASINQO AND THE NATURE OF QANAT", which is a Phd Thesis consisting of field work from Addis Ababa. Addis Ababa is a city where the majority ethnic group is Amhara. Qanat is also an old Amharic word. We link these scale to Amhara.
